Russell E. Bidlack Papers, ca. 1940s-2003

Finding aid created by

did.abstract: Russell Bidlack was the first Dean of the School of Library Science at the University of Michigan, serving in that post from 1969 to 1984, as well as an author and historian. His papers reflect his interests in library science, local history, and genealogy.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in periodic accessions by Professor Russell Bidlack (donor no. 2635). The most recent accession came from the Bidlack family in 2004. The Rumsey research files were received from Philip P. Johnson (donor no. 9977) in 2007.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Russell E. Bidlack Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Russell Bidlack was born on May 25, 1920 near Manilla, Iowa. He obtained his bachelor degree in English from Simpson College in 1947. Subsequently, he received a master degree in history in 1950, and a doctorate in library science in 1954, both from the University of Michigan. He spent his entire academic career with the Department of Library Science at the University of Michigan, which elevated him to the rank of full professor in 1965. In 1967, Bidlack became acting chairman of the department. He then oversaw the transition as the department became a separate academic unit within the university. In 1969, Bidlack was appointed the first dean of the new School of Library Science. He retired from this position in 1984. His retirement years were busy with his research, lecturing and writings about Ann Arbor history and genealogy (notably his Sparks Quarterly newsletter). Dean Bidlack died September 18, 2003.

Bidlack wrote extensively on topics in the field of library science. He was also an expert on library accreditation, helping to write a set of standards, and serving for many years as the chair of the American Library Association's committee on accreditation.

scopecontent.p: The Bidlack papers consist of seven series: Correspondence, Personal Material, Class Notes, Miscellaneous Files, Writings, the John and Ann Allen Research files, and the Elisha and Mary Ann Rumsey Research Files.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (0.4 linear feet) is comprised of two subseries: that relating to his tenure at the University of Michigan, and that relating to his work with the Sparks Quarterly.

did.unittitle: Appointment as Dean of School of Library Science (press releases, letters) 1969
Search for Dean of School of Library Science 1968
Papers relating to campaign to purchase brick at Michigan Stadium in the name of library science professor Ken Vance 1996

scopecontent.p: The Personal Material series consists of photographs from Bidlack's retirement party on April 6, 1984 and a brochure from his memorial in 2003.

The Class Notes series (0.5 linear feet) consist of handwritten notes on numerous library science subjects and used in lectures on such topics as cataloging, classification, and indexing. Some of these notes were probably created by Katherine Schwartz, a professor whose tenure preceded and briefly overlapped with Bidlack's.

Of interest in the Miscellaneous Files series is a file of youth services brochures from major U.S. public libraries, ca. 1953. There is also a video from the bicentennial celebration of Ann Allen and material relating to the Willow Run Village dating from 1948-1958.

did.unittitle: Youth Services Brochures from Major U.S. Public Libraries circa 1953
Ann Arbor Quarry pictures painted by Milton Kemnitz
Havens and Van Fossen Sons of the Revolution papers

scopecontent.p: The Writings series (2 linear feet) contains many of Dean Bidlack's research notes on his wide-ranging interests. The series is divided into History - Miscellaneous, University of Michigan, Library Science and History, Ann Arbor History (unrelated to the Allen Family), and his research on the California Gold Rush of 1849 which resulted in the book "Letters Home: The Story of Ann Arbor's Forty-Niners" and Genealogy.

John and Ann Allen Research files

scopecontent.p: The John and Ann Allen Research files (2 linear feet) contains research notes, transcriptions and photocopies of original documents, and correspondence with individuals and repositories. The papers divide into five subseries: Ann Allen, Allen Family, Michigan History, Related Families and Correspondence (Alphabetical by name of family or correspondent), and Augusta County, Virginia research. Drafts and notes for his books "Ann Arbor's First Lady: Event in the Life of Ann I. Allen" and "John Allen and the Founding of Ann Arbor" are also included.

scopecontent.p: The Elisha and Mary Ann Rumsey Research Files (1 linear ft.) includes correspondence with Rumsey family members and research institutions, notes, typescripts of various documents compiled by Russell Bidlack in the course of his research for the booklet “The Short and Troubled Lives of Elisha and Mary Ann Rumsey.”
